I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  A  modern  and  market-friendly  legal  system,  which  clearly  defines  and  effectively 
reinforces legal rights for citizens and enterprises and is easily accessible to the poor, is 
fundamental in the transition from a centrally planned to a market economy. To support its 
transition from a centrally planned to a socialist-oriented market economy, Viet Nam has been 
engaged in the momentous task of constructing a new legal system. The 1992 Constitution, with 
the National Assembly’s resolution of 2001, reflects this effort by underlining that Viet Nam is a 
socialist state governed by the rule of law. 
  
2.  The legal system development needs assessment (LNA), initiated by the Ministry of 
Justice  (MOJ)  under  a  multiagency  -  funded  preparatory  assistance  (PA)  project,  aims  at 
developing a strategy and subsequently an action plan for developing a comprehensive legal 
system in Viet Nam. After successfully completing the LNA study and submitting its report to the 
Prime Minister in July 2002, MOJ received a go-ahead from the Prime Minister’s Office for 
further work on the strategy for developing a comprehensive legal system up to year 2010. 
Since 2000, aid agencies including the Asian Development Bank (ADB), have been supporting 
this initiative. In 1997, at the request of the Government, ADB provided technical assistance 
(TA) to MOJ for developing a national registry system for secured transactions (TA-2823 VIE).1 
Its final report contains a design for further developing and expanding the  secured transactions 
registration system, including a national database and nation wide computerized network for the 
registry.2 Further expansion of registry services for secured transactions, including drafting of 
appropriate ordinances, is included in the measures and actions set out in the Financial Sector 
Program Loan II.3 
 
3.  The  Government  of  Viet  Nam  has  requested  ADB  to  grant  an  advisory  technical 
assistance (TA) to help (i) prepare implementation mechanisms for a Strategy for developing 
the Viet Nam legal system up to year 2010 (SLSD) and (ii) build the capacity of the National 
Registration Agency of Secured Transactions (NRAST). A Fact-Finding Mission4 from ADB 
visited Hanoi during 4-28 October 2002 to discuss with the Government the TA’s objectives, 
scope, and implementation arrangements.5 A wrap up meeting held on 25 October 2002 at MOJ 
to discussed the Mission’s findings and finalized the proposed TA, and a memorandum of 
understanding was signed on 29 October 2002. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
   
4.  Legal System Development. Both the Party and the Government recognize that the 
establishment and improvement of the legal system are essential parts of the Government’s 
continuing policy reform to meet the aspirations of the people. Experience shows that to reach 
the targets of the socio-economic development strategy for 2001-2010, it is necessary to have a

5.  Building on the success of the LNA, a multiagency-funded Joint Formulation Mission 
(JFM) was held for 4 weeks starting from 4 November 2002 to map out priority areas and 
external  support,6  and  to  prepare  a  comprehensive  project  document  on  mechanism  for 
implementing SLSD. The LNA report indicates 5 program areas7 with 27 subprograms and 268 
activities. Of the activities, 130 are categorized as priority projects, which the Government 
wishes to implement first with external support. The SLSD cuts across many sectors; it is also 
an important area embracing the Public Administration Reform – Master Program, 2001-2010.  
 
6.  Secured  Transaction  Registry.  A  system  of  securing  assets,  both  movable  and 
immovable,  is  fundamental  in  creating  an  effective  credit  market.  Credit  is  essential  for 
economic and industrial development for it allows credit providers and entrepreneurs to pursue 
projects, including purchase of property and development of infrastructure, in anticipation of 
investment returns or future earnings. If there is a legal regime for secured transactions that is 
perceived to give the providers of credit adequate protection from and remedies for failures of 
debtors to pay, then security on property can become a major element of the investment 
decision of both domestic and international investors. Security measures and an adequate legal 
framework  therefore  play  an  important  role  in  mobilizing  capital  to  meet  investors’  needs. 
Borrowers also benefit from increased availability of credit, improved credit terms, and relatively 
reduced costs. Building the capacity for a secured transactions registry complements financial 
sector reform, particularly in developing an effective credit market. 
 
7.  Following  the  Prime  Minister’s  decision,  a  dedicated  department  for  the  purpose 
(NRAST) was established in 2001. MOJ has established pilot branches (i.e., points of service, 
POS) in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC). In Hanoi, over a period of about 7 months, the 
total number of registrations of security reached 10,000. Since the Ho Chi Minh City branch 
began operation in August 2002, about 2,000 transactions have been registered. Although very 
encouraging, these numbers are only a small fraction of the potential. The lack of adequate 
technical capacity and public awareness, and also the scope of the current legal framework for 
this purpose constrain progress.  
 
 
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
8.  The TA is designed to address the noted issues in a two-pronged approach. It will assist 
MOJ in (i) preparing implementation mechanisms for SLSD and (ii) building capacity of NRAST. 
The  first  component,  technical  support  in  preparing  implementation  mechanisms  for  a 
comprehensive legal system leading up to 2010, will have special focus on priority projects 
selected  by  MOJ.  The  second  component  will  entail  drafting  an  ordinance  for  registering 
secured  transactions,  improving  the  organization  and  operation  of  the  registration  system, 
increasing POS, legal training, and public education and publicity programs.  
 
                                                           
6   VRM staff took part in the JFM. 
7   The five areas are (i) legislative and law-making reform; (ii) judicial reforms; (iii) effective implementation of laws 
and regulations; (iv) legal information system and legal dissemination; and (v) legal education, and judicial and 
legal professional training.

3 
9.  The SLSD-related work will support the systematic reform of legal systems and improve 
governance in general, and at the same time provide a better legal environment for businesses 
as well as citizens. An improved and easily accessible registry of secured transactions will help 
to achieve improved transparency, accountability, and predictability. The improvement, in turn, 
will  attract  investors  and  help  small  as  well  as  big  businesses,  households  as  well  as 
enterprises, with improved credit terms and facilities.  
 
10.  The expected major deliverables and outcomes are (i) implementation mechanisms for 
SLSD, including project document and implementation plan for selected priority projects; (ii) 
enhanced capacity of NRAST to provide registration services for secured transactions; (iii) four 
more  POS  leading  to  increased  registration  facility  and  access  to  information  on  secured 
transactions; (iv) increased public awareness of legal system reforms and development; and (v) 
increased credit facilities and improved credit terms in the long run.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  Support to SLSD. Through international and domestic legal experts, the TA will assist 
the PA project of MOJ in formulating implementation mechanisms for SLSD, with special focus 
on selected priority projects in legal reform. The work will, among others, entail (i) identifying 
and developing projects in priority areas to be agreed upon with MOJ and (ii) conducting 
workshops and seminars for consensus building and discussing the proposed project concept 
and implementation plans. The work will take into account JFM findings and recommendations, 
and formulate implementation mechanisms, as appropriate, in consultation with the LNA-Inter 
Agency Steering Committee and in close coordination with other aid agencies. 
 
12.  Drafting Ordinance. The TA will help prepare a draft ordinance or a higher level legal 
instrument as necessary for the registration of secured transactions and broaden its scope to 
include immovable assets and other property. International experts will make recommendations 
on the content of the draft ordinance, and they will coordinate with Vietnamese experts to 
prepare and complete the draft ordinance in close consultation with MOJ and the State Bank of 
Viet Nam (SBV). MOJ will submit the draft ordinance to the Government for eventual approval 
by  the  National  Assembly  Steering  Committee.  MOJ  and  SBV  will  coordinate  the 
implementation of the ordinance. 
 
13.  Capacity Building and Training.  The capacity building and training support under the 
TA covers four main areas: improving the organization and operation of the registration system 
of secured transactions; technical support to new registry offices; training in registering secured 
transactions; and assisting in the public education and publicity program. First, the TA, with the 
help of international experts, will study the organization and process of registering secured 
transactions in the Hanoi and HCMC offices and identify areas for improvement. Drawing on 
study findings and international good practices, the experts will make recommendations for 
better organization of registry operations for both movable and immovable assets, including and 
information and technology (IT) system for registration and also for public information. The 
recommended modality will be used to improve registration work in existing as well as new 
registry offices. The IT system in each registry will also be a step to achieving a centralized 
system by eventual linking each POS with the nation-wide computerized system.8 Second, the 
TA will assist NRAST in establishing pilot registry offices at four new sites in the country by 
                                                           
8  The  computerization  program  is  expected  to  be  implemented  in  early  2003,  almost  in  parallel  with  the 
implementation of the proposed TA.

4  
 
providing technical support in putting in place a registry system and an IT system, and in 
training the required staff. 
 
14.  Third, the TA will assess the training needs of NRAST and its customers, and then 
design training curricula that cover both the concept and operation of secured transactions 
registration. The training activities will be directed to trainers; NRAST staff, existing and new; 
potential institutional customers, including officials and experts from SBV, commercial banks, 
credit  organizations,  finance  companies,  and  government  ministries  and  agencies.  Users 
training will be confined to the cities where registry offices are established. International experts 
jointly with trained NRAST trainers will conduct the training workshops. They will also prepare 
training materials such as handbooks in hard copy as well as in CD-ROMs for self-learning 
through the web site. The NRAST trainers and experts will conduct similar training workshops in 
the future, using these training materials to meet the future training requirements in all cities with 
POS. 
 
15.  Fourth, international and domestic experts and NRAST staff in consultation with SBV 
staff, will, among others, design public education and publicity (information package) at local 
levels; develop a web site for NRAST for wider publicity and public education, and implement 
the publicity programs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $940,000 equivalent, of which $ 380,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost, and $560,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. The Government has 
requested that the ADB finance $750,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign currency cost 
and $370,000 equivalent of the local currency cost (Appendix 1). The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance the balance of the local 
currency cost equivalent to $190,000 by providing counterpart support, office accommodation, 
basic office equipment and supplies, local communication and transport, local information and 
documents required by the consultants.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  MOJ will be the Executing Agency. MOJ will appoint Project Directors, who will manage 
day-to-day activities related to SLSD and NRAST, and coordinate with other agencies and 
concerned parties, particularly SBV.  
 
18.  To support legal system development up to year 2010, four individual experts for a total 
of  21  person-months  will  be  engaged:  one  international  consultant  for  legal  system 
development, six person-months and three domestic consultants (a finance legal specialist; 
legal specialist on transition, trade and integration and a legal education and training specialist), 
each with 5 person-months. To build capacity for secured transactions registration, international 
and domestic experts to provide 38 person-months services will be engaged through a firm 
using the quality and cost-based selection method and simplified technical proposal. There will 
be three international and ten domestic consultants; terms of reference are in Appendix 2. One 
third of the TA resources (i.e $250,000) will be devoted to assisting MOJ in SLSD-related work; 
and the rest (i.e $500,000) to capacity building for secured transactions registration. The TA will 
be implemented over 30 months. The ADB will engage consultants in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging 
domestic consultants in consultation with MOJ. The consultants and implementing agencies (i.e

5 
NRAST)  will  procure  equipment  required  under  the  TA  following  ADB’s  Guidelines  for 
Procurement. Viet Nam Resident Mission working closely with OGC will implement the TA. 
 
19.  To effectively conclude the TA and to address the complex nature of the legal reform 
issues and the need for a forward-looking approach, both the Government and ADB have 
agreed to maintain some flexibility during implementation. MOJ will ensure timely provision and 
release of the necessary financial and human resources for setting up of registry offices in four 
new  locations  in  the  country  and  provide  necessary  logistics  and  coordination  for 
implementation. MOJ and ADB will regularly monitor and review the progress of implementation. 
Appendix 3 gives the TA framework. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Legal System Development up to Year 2010 and Capacity 
Building for Secured Transactions Registration, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Support to Legal System Development up to Year 2010 
 
1.  International Expert in Legal System Development 
1.  This component of the technical assistance (TA) will require 6 person-months inputs of 
an international expert in legal system development intermittently during the implementation 
period.  
 
2.  The  expertise  required  is  developing  a  legal  system  in  the  transition  economies  in 
general  and  Viet  Nam  in  particular,  encompassing  finance,  regional  and  international 
integration, and human resource development, including skills in developing and identifying 
project. Knowledge of Vietnamese legal reform issues and work experience in this regard will be 
an advantage. 
 
3.  The key tasks of the international expert are to (i) assist the preparatory assistance 
project  of  the  Ministry  of  Justice  (MOJ)  in  formulating  Strategy  for  Viet  Nam’s  Legal 
Development up to year 2010 (SLSD) and its implementation mechanisms, with special focus 
on  priority  projects  in  legal  reform,  by  reviewing  the  legal  system  development  needs 
assessment (LNA) report, Inter-Agency Steering Committee (IASC) report and Joint Formulation 
Mission (JFM) findings; and by undertaking additional work as appropriate; (ii) identify and 
develop projects in priority areas in consultation with MOJ and key aid agencies; and (iii) 
conduct workshops and seminars to build consensus and discuss the proposed project concept 
and implementation plans. 
 
2.  Domestic Consultants 
 
4.  In addition, the TA will require 15 person-months inputs of domestic legal experts who 
will work closely with the international expert in legal system development to accomplish the 
tasks in paragraph 3. The domestic consultants (3, each with 5 person-months inputs, covering 
finance and integration areas, and legal education and training) will have in-depth knowledge of 
the Vietnamese legal systems, and legal and judicial reform issues, and will be well versed in 
applying such knowledge in developing a legal system. They should have at least a university 
degree in law, work experience of at least 10 years, and English language proficiency. 
 
5.  The consultants will be selected as individuals. 
 
B.  Capacity Building for Secured Transactions Registration 
 
1.  International Experts 
 
6.  This component of the TA will require 8 person-month inputs of international experts 
during  implementation.  The  required  expertise  comprises  legal  drafting  skills,  concept  and 
operation of registering secured transactions, training, and public awareness programs. The 
consultants will have knowledge of the Vietnamese legal system and financial sector reform 
initiatives and work experience in this regard in Viet Nam or in other countries. Expertise in 
more than one area will be an advantage. The key tasks and areas of responsibility of the 
international experts (with person-month in paranthesis) are summarized here.

administration,  with  15  years  experience  in  secured  transactions  registration  and  public 
information; familiarity/experience with the legal and financial sectors of transition economies;

2.  Domestic Consultants 
 
9.  In  addition,  up  to  10  domestic  consultants,  will  provide  30  person-month  inputs 
intermittently during the TA implementation.  
 
10.  Domestic experts will assist NRAST and the international experts to achieve the TA 
objectives  and  outputs.  Their  expertise  positions  (number  of  experts  and  person-month  in 
parenthesis and main tasks will be as follows:  
 
a.  Legal drafting experts (2 persons, 2 months each) will assist in drafting the 
ordinance, comment on the draft prepared by international experts, and participate in the 
consultation process to finalize the draft.  
b.  Organization and management experts (2 persons, 2 months each) will assist 
in improving the organization and operation of the registry system.  
c.  Legal  and  public  awareness  training  experts  (1  person  for  registration 
operations training for 5 person-months and 1 for public awareness for 5 person-months) 
will assist in the design and conduct of training and public awareness activities.  
d.  Banking and financial sector expert (1 person for 4 months) will assist in 
analytical work related to the banking and financial sectors as they relate to secured 
transactions and also support legal experts in these areas.  
e.  IT experts (2 persons for 4 months each) will design and implement information 
and communication technology application for registry offices, NRAST, and a web site 
for NRAST.  
 
11.  The domestic experts should have a law or business degree and at least 10 years 
experience in the Vietnamese legal system, and banking and financial sectors. They should 
have a good knowledge of the Vietnamese legal sector, excellent legal drafting skill, training 
experience, good team spirit, and proficiency in English. The IT expert should have an IT 
degree and related professional training in IT applications, system design and maintenance, and 
web site design and implementation for public information campaign. Domestic experts with 
more than one skill will be preferred. 
 
12.  A team of international and domestic experts will be selected through a consulting firm 
following the simplified technical proposal and quality and cost-based basis.
